awd_titl_txt: RTG: Enhancing American Research Leadership in Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Mathematical innovations often arise from the interplay between ideas from physics and from traditional mathematics. However, it has become increasingly difficult for researchers in one field to understand the ideas and advances in the other. The purpose of this program is to train young mathematicians collaboratively at a traditional mathematics department and at a research center devoted to the interactions between mathematics and theoretical physics. The goal is produce mathematicians of the next generation who will have both the tools to succeed in their chosen fields and the facility necessary to bridge the gap between areas.

This project will establish a Research Training Group in geometry as a collaborative effort between the Stony Brook Mathematics Department and the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics. It unites a long commitment to training young mathematicians at a traditional mathematics department with the exceptional scientific opportunities presented by a major international research center located next door. The overall aim of the program is to train a group of young mathematicians who will combine expertise in a specific geometric field with a serious appreciation of the other subfields of geometry and of the connections between geometry and mathematical physics. The RTG will have three main components. It will fund nine Postdoctoral Fellows who will be full participating members of both the mathematics department and the Simons Center. Besides engaging in a full range of traditional mathematical activities, the Fellows will participate in joint seminars bringing together postdocs in mathematics and theoretical physics. The program will also provide partial support to a cadre of graduate trainees in mathematics, who will have an affiliation in the Simons Center and will participate fully in activities in the Center. Finally, the program will put in place a number of new activities designed to enrich the experiences of Stony Brook mathematics undergraduates, including those interested in teaching careers, and to introduce them to the scientific focus of the Simons Center.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded a Research Training Group (RTG) in geometry at Stony Brook University, from early 2016 to early 2025. This was a joint project between the mathematics department and the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics (SCGP). The principal idea was to unite a commitment to training young mathematicians (undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows) at a traditional math department with the exceptional opportunities presented by a major international center devoted to research in geometry and physics. One accomplishment of the RTG is better integration and communication between the department and SCGP, for example in making joint decisions about postdoc hiring.

The RTG supported seven postdoctoral fellows, joint between the math department and SCGP, in addition to the regular Simons instructors and SCGP postdocs. Their presence strengthened our program in geometry. Six of the seven found permanent academic positions afterwards. The RTG also offered research fellowships to a substantial number of graduate students, one semester at a time. Before the pandemic, the RTG funded summer research by undergraduate students and Stony Brook faculty (REU) as well as research projects by future middle and high school teachers (RET). With support from the RTG, a group of graduate students started a Directed Reading Program; this runs every spring semester and pairs 10-20 undergraduate students with a graduate student mentor for a reading project about a specific mathematical topic.

The RTG led to the creation of several new activities in the department that will continue after the end of the grant. To better integrate postdocs and graduate students into the department, we now have short talks by all the new postdocs at the beginning, and short lectures by finishing graduate students at the end of the academic year. A new seminar, organized by postdocs, helps first and second year graduate students find advisers and navigate our program. The RTG also introduced a professional development seminar with practical advice and many guest speakers from industry, with the goal of preparing our students for non-academic jobs. As a result of this, the department is now a member of the Erdös Institute, which offers this kind of career advice and networking on a much larger scale.

The RTG funded several big outreach events, called "Math Days", that were attended by undergraduate students from the greater New York area, and that served to advertise our graduate program. It supported a total of seven graduate spring/summer schools, each one or two weeks long, that introduced groups of graduate students to advanced topics in computational geometry, the mathematical aspects of general relativity, Teichmueller spaces, mixed Hodge modules, algebraic groups, and fluid dynamics. It also contributed to the first two Simons Math Summer Workshops at the Simons Center for Geometry and Physics.
